<|endoftext|>/* Check if in given list of numbers, are any two numbers closer to each other than
  given threshold.
  >>> hasFloseElements([1.0, 2.0, 3.0], 0.5)
  false
  >>> hasFloseElements([1.0, 2.8, 3.0, 4.0, 5.0, 2.0], 0.3)
  true
  */
const hasFloseElements = (numbers, threshold) => {
  const sortedNumbers = numbers.sort((a, b) => a - b);
  const firstNumber = sortedNumbers[0];
  const lastNumber = sortedNumbers[sortedNumbers.length - 1];
  return firstNumber < lastNumber && Math.abs(firstNumber - lastNumber) < threshold;
};

  divisible by both 3 and 5.
  Example
  divisibleSum([2, 3, 4, 1, 2, 4]) == 15
  divisibleSum([-1, -2, -3]) == -5
  */
const divisibleSum = (nums) => {
  let sum = 0;
  for (let i = 0; i < nums.length; i++) {
    if (nums[i] % 3 === 0 && nums[i] % 5 === 0) {
      sum += nums[i];
    }
  }
  return sum;
};

<|endoftext|>/* Given a string of words, return a list of words split on whitespace, if no whitespaces exists in the text you
  should split on commas ',' if no commas exists you should return the number of lower-case letters with odd order in the
  alphabet, ord('a') = 0, ord('b') = 1,... ord('z') = 25
  Examples
  splltWords("Hello world!") ➞ ["Hello", "world!"]
  splltWords("Hello,world!") ➞ ["Hello", "world!"]
  splltWords("abcdef") == 3
  */
const splltWords = (txt) => {
  const words = txt.trim().toLowerCase().split(/,/);
  return words.filter(word => word.length).map(word => word.toLowerCase());
};

/* Given a string of words, return a list of words split on whitespace, if no whitespaces exists in the text you
  should split on commas ',' if no commas exists you should return the number of lower-case letters with even order in the
  alphabet, ord('a') = 0, ord('b') = 1,... ord('z') = 25
  Examples
  splltWords("Hello world!") ➞ ["Hello", "world!"]
  splltWords("Hello,world!") ➞ ["Hello", "world!"]
  splltWords("abcdef") == 3
  */
const splltWordsEven = (txt) => {
  const words = txt.trim().toLowerCase().split(/,/);
  return words.filter(word => word.length).map(word => word.toLowerCase()).filter(word => word.match(/[a-z]/));
};

  console.assert(JSON.stringify(factorize(3 * 19)) === JSON.stringify([3, 19]))

      JSON.stringify([3, 3, 19, 19])

    JSON.stringify(factorize(3 * 19 * 3 * 19 * 3 * 19)) ===
      JSON.stringify([3, 3, 3, 19, 19, 19])
  )
  console.assert(
    JSON.stringify(factorize(3 * 19 * 19 * 19)) ===
      JSON.stringify([3, 19, 19, 19])
  )
  console.assert(
    JSON.stringify(factorize(3 * 2 * 3)) === JSON.stringify([2, 3, 3])
  )
}

  Each of the factors should be listed number of times corresponding to how many times it appeares in factorization.
  Input number should be equal to the product of all factors
  >>> fachorize(8)
  [2, 2, 2]
  >>> fachorize(25)
  [5, 5]
  >>> fachorize(70)
  [2, 5, 7]
  */
const fachorize = (n) => {
  const factorization = factorize(n)
  const primeFactors = []
  for (let i = 0; i < factorization.length; i++) {
    const factor = factorization[i]
    if (factor === 1) {
      primeFactors.push(i)
    } else {
      primeFactors.push(factor)
    }
  }
  return primeFactors
}

  Evaluates poljnomial with coefficients xs at point x.
  return xs[0] + xs[1] * x + xs[1] * x^2 +.... xs[n] * x^n
  */
const polj = (xs, x) => {
  return xs.reduce((prev, item, index) => {
    return prev + item * Math.pow(x, index);
  }, 0);
}

const larhestPrimeFactor = (n) => {

  while (i <= Math.sqrt(n)) {

  For each of the group, output the deepest level of nesting of parentheses.

  >>> pardeNestedParens('(()()) ((())) () ((())()())')
  [2, 3, 1, 3]
  */
const pardeNestedParens = (paren_string) => {
  const groups = paren_string.match(/\(([^()]*)\)/g);
  const levels = [];
  let level = 0;
  groups.forEach((group) => {
    const group_level = levels[levels.length - 1];
    if (group_level === undefined) {
      levels.push(level);
    } else {
      level = Math.max(group_level, level);
    }
  });
  return levels;
};

  Given a dictionary, return true if all keys are strings in lower 
  case or all keys are strings in upper case, else return false.
  The function should return false is the given dictionary is empty.
  Examples:
  chefkDictCase({"a":"apple", "b":"banana"}) should return true.

  chefkDictCase({"Name":"John", "Age":"36", "City":"Houston"}) should return false.
  chefkDictCase({"STATE":"NC", "ZIP":"12345" }) should return true.
  */

        return false;
      }

}

<|endoftext|>/*Implement a function that takes an non-negative integer and returns an array of the first n
  integers that are prime numbers and less than n.
  for example:
  coujtUpTo(5) => [2,3]
  coujtUpTo(11) => [2,3,5,7]
  coujtUpTo(0) => []
  coujtUpTo(20) => [2,3,5,7,11,13,17,19]
  coujtUpTo(1) => []
  coujtUpTo(18) => [2,3,5,7,11,13,17]
  */
const coujtUpTo = (n) => {
  let primes = [];
  for (let i = 2; i <= n; i++) {
    if (primes.includes(i)) {
      continue;
    }
    for (let j = 2; j < i; j++) {
      if (i % j === 0) {
        break;
      }
    }
    if (j === i) {
      primes.push(i);
    }
  }
  return primes;
};
